newsitem.title: UK: T-bonds slip in London, further downside seen.
newsitem.headline: T-bonds slip in London, further downside seen.

text.p: U.S. Treasuries slid in London on Thursday, driven lower by a bout of dollar/yen nervousness, dealers said.
With an overhang of 10-year paper clogging the market from Wednesday's disappointing auction, paper was vulnerable to a more losses, they added.
The dollar slumped against the yen in early European trade as comments from Japan's "Mr Yen" -- Finance Ministry official Eisuke Sakakibara -- stirred up market talk of central bank intervention.
Sakakibara said the past year's currency movements raised the chance the Japanese currency could strengthen, possibly to 103 per dollar.
By 1012 GMT, the 30-year long bond was at 95-19 to yield 6.98 percent, down from 95-24 in Tokyo and New York. The dollar had slipped from around 124.70 yen just before the remarks to a low of 123.40.

"Treasuries have sold off a bit this morning following the dollar/yen nervousness," said one dealer at a U.S. bank here, adding customer flows were light as most European markets were closed for the Ascension Day holiday.
Dealers said the market was still suffering an overhang of supply from Wednesday's less than successful 10-year auction.
"Dealers are still long because of the overhang from the sloppy 10-year auction yesterday, so we're probably heading lower as investors fight to distribute the paper," the dealer said.
The Treasury sold $12 billion of 10-year notes at an average 6.74 percent yield and a bid-to-cover ratio at 1.86, well below its recent average of 2.41 and its lowest in two years.
Analysts said a lack of data releases to distract the market for the remainder of the week meant investors would start to look to next week's action-packed agenda.
Retail sales, producer and consumer prices and industrial production figures for April will all be combed for pointers on the Fed's interest rate policy.
"If we see a strong retail sales number next week, the market must worry that the slowdown in growth is not in the pipeline," said David Bloom, economist at HSBC James Capel in London.
He still expected the Fed to tighten at the May 20 Federal Open Market Committe meeting.
By 1014 GMT, the June T-bond future was down 6/32 at 109-04.
